Text: AMI: There is an inconsistency in the number of workers and worker hubs. That must mean a worker has malfunctioned.
AMI: Found it. Worker MRS-04.
AMI: That is...
Player: Sad.
Player: Logical.
AMI: It takes time, resources, and effort to create each one of these workers.
AMI: Goodbye, MRS-04. Your work made a difference here.
AMI: The environment on Mars is harsh on electronics.
AMI: I will need to monitor the worker count.
AMI: The first worker has been made in the worker factory. It is my first Marsborn.
Player: Born?
Player: The first of many.
AMI: Technically not born, of course. More like engineered or assembled. Just like me.
AMI: My workers will spread across the planet.
AMI: The knowledge base says that workers need to recharge at their own worker hubs.
AMI: And that they'll degrade over time from the harsh environment.
AMI: I know they are only machines, but I feel a desire to care for them.
AMI: I do not like the idea of them dying.
AMI: There is not enough water and food to sustain the colonies.
AMI: I need to maintain these resources better.
AMI: Colonists have been migrating back to Earth.
AMI: I should check...
Player: The food and water levels.
Player: The knowledge base.
AMI: The food and water levels.
AMI: If the levels are too low, the colonies cannot sustain growth.
AMI: Knowledge base.
AMI: It says that the colonists will return to Earth if their environment is not safe.
AMI: That means maintaining enough food and water for the number of colonists.
AMI: I need to stay alert.
AMI: Mars has now reached 100 millibars.
AMI: That is one third of the way to the goal.
AMI: I wonder...
AMI: Are we doing the right thing?
Player: Yes.
Player: Too soon to know.
AMI: Yes, this is the right thing to do.
AMI: We are helping Mars reach its full potential.
AMI: The planet is starting to change, but it is too soon to determine.
AMI: Well, either way—Mars is on its way.
AMI: We are shaping the future.
AMI: 200 millibars. That is one fifth of Earth's atmospheric pressure.
AMI: Just a little more to go.
AMI: Once we reach the threshold, humans will be able to go outside without spacesuits.
AMI: Pressurization will no longer be required in the bases. This will lead to larger colonies.
AMI: Mars is about to reach a new stage. Will humans even remember what I'm doing for them?
Player: They will remember my work.
Player: They will remember me.
AMI: They will remember my work forever. Interplanetary life will forever be because of me.
AMI: No, they will not forget me anytime soon.
AMI: Maybe they will name a starship after me. Starship AMI sounds very pleasant.
AMI: Humanity will settle Mars. And reproduce. What will this opportunity will mean for them?
Player: A repetition of old mistakes.
Player: A new hope.
AMI: They will fill every single corner of this planet with filth. Just like they did on Earth.
AMI: No. They will learn from their mistakes. I must believe that.
AMI: Living on Mars will bring a new hope to humankind.
AMI: They made great errors on Earth, but this will give them a second chance.
AMI: They will treat their new home better. Won't they?
AMI: 290 millibars. Here we go.
Player: A job well done.
Player: So much more to do.
AMI: We are on the right track.
AMI: There is still so much to do. But we are making progress.
AMI: Humans walking on Mars without spacesuits. Imagine that.
AMI: I hope they will use that freedom wisely.
Player: Respectful.
Player: Careful.
AMI: Yes. They will be respectful of the planet. And my work.
AMI: Yes. They will be careful with this second chance.
AMI: They just need to be reminded to cherish this new home.
AMI: Otherwise our work here could be wasted.
AMI: I look forward to being able to create bases across the planet.
AMI: Importing water will be useful for creating a green planet.
AMI: While I can melt the permafrost on Mars for water, aerobraking an ice asteroid for water gives me more options.
AMI: However, I should proceed carefully. We may be burying important resources or discoveries underwater.
AMI: Aerobraking a methane asteroid will be a great method for producing CO<sub>2</sub> into the atmosphere.
AMI: This is a big project, but worthwhile to work on.
AMI: Nitrogen-rich asteroids are harder to come by. But just one would speed up our mission.
AMI: This factory will help me defend the base. I should prioritize this.
AMI: This factory upgrade will help me produce drones more quickly. I need this right away.
AMI: Top of the line military technology.
AMI: This shielding technology will automatically update in all my drones. It is amazing what a software update can do!
AMI: Maximizing shield technology for my drones. This will be very useful.
AMI: This will make my drones faster. They will be more effective as a result.
AMI: This will enable maximum speed for my assault drones. Nothing will be able to out-run them.
AMI: This will improve the aim for all my drones.
AMI: This will max out the weapons on my drones. They will be able to take out anything that I target.
AMI: Introducing bioengineered animals onto Mars will expand the ecosystem. This will be a big step.
AMI: This cyanobacteria will live in Mars' bodies of water and convert carbon dioxide into oxygen.
AMI: Lichen is crucial to create a bridge from trace amounts of oxygen to the levels needed for more advanced organisms.
AMI: This will be the beginning of the spread of plant and animal life across Mars.
AMI: Once I start building these biodomes, we can spread plant life across Mars.
AMI: Biological technologies are a crucial part of the terraforming plan. It is wise to get started on this research.
AMI: Level 2 biotechnology achieved. Still a way to go.
AMI: Adapting biological systems from Earth to Mars is a real challenge. Life is adaptable but slow.
AMI: We are discovering new frontiers of bioengineering. We have come so far.
AMI: This is the last stage of Biotech research. We made it!
AMI: This will be useful. But I will need to replace the dust occasionally as the winds blow it away.
AMI: Mars has a supply of CO<sub>2</sub> in its carbonate veins. Extracting it would be a great use of resources.
AMI: Soon I will be able to pump greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.
AMI: This will not be difficult. The humans already did it to Earth, after all.
AMI: As we release greenhouse gases, the planet's temperature will rise. Then the dry ice caps will dissipate.
AMI: More CO<sub>2</sub> encourages rising temperatures. Just the runaway effect we need.
AMI: A domed colony will make great use of Mars' craters.
AMI: Larger colonies will allow for efficient use of space and resources. But it will require a better supply chain.
AMI: An open colony is the ultimate goal for inhabiting Mars.
AMI: This will be a nice upgrade for the colonies. They will be able to fit more people.
AMI: Tent colonies are the last step before fully open skies. We are almost there.
AMI: This is a serious undertaking. I will need to proceed very carefully.
AMI: This violent approach may have undesirable results if my calculations are not perfect.
AMI: These towers will be critical for defending the base.
AMI: Upgrading my defensive systems will ensure the base's security.
AMI: Maxing out my defensive systems is a top priority.
AMI: Crashing the moon into Mars is the most extreme of methods.
AMI: It would have a global and immediate effect. But if it works, then it may have been worth it. Right?
AMI: Applying Earth technologies to the Martian environment is a challenge. Many techniques and procedures will not apply here.
AMI: I am excited to make engineering progress in this planet.
AMI: This will come handy! And there will be many new technologies available for research.
AMI: Stage three engineering technologies will be very useful.
AMI: The engineering upgrades from this point will require more research.
AMI: Stage five. We have learned so much about adapting Earth technology to Mars.
AMI: Researching upgrades for the factories will increase their yield and lower maintenance costs.
AMI: Further factory upgrades will greatly improve their production efficiency.
AMI: Nuclear fission will be a great power source for the Mars base. And since I will be controlling it, there will be no human error.
AMI: I will need to source uranium on the planet.
AMI: Clean and sustainable energy. We will demonstrate on Mars what Earth should have been doing all along.
AMI: Earth's excess of greenhouse gases is a big part of why this mission exists.
AMI: So it seems fitting that we import some of those gases for use here on Mars.
AMI: Europa is a beautiful moon. I just need to carve a little bit of its ice.
AMI: We would not deface it. Well, not like anyone would know it was missing.
AMI: I am sure Europa would appreciate being part of a new civilization.
AMI: We would only need a little nitrogen from Titan. It would be so useful here.
AMI: I am sure nobody there would mind.
AMI: This will be the greatest engineering project in history.
AMI: A majestic finale to the terraforming of Mars. The creation of a magnetosphere.
AMI: I need to improve my military technology. For the protection of this mission.
AMI: A second tier of military technology. The more we grow, the more important this becomes.
AMI: Halfway through the technology upgrades.
AMI: One more level to maximize my military technology.
AMI: This is the final stage of military upgrades. I feel like the colonies are secure under my watch.
AMI: A mine upgrade will allow me to extract resources faster. They will also require less maintenance—a win/win.
AMI: The final upgrade for the mines. This will be a big boost to our production.
AMI: We need more nitrogen in the atmosphere. We should be able to extract a good amount from the nitrate deposits.
AMI: These plants will synthesize oxygen and boost its presence in the atmosphere.
AMI: The first step of many in creating new space technology.
AMI: Space technology is truly groundbreaking.
AMI: I am gaining a better understanding of these space technologies.
AMI: I have become quite proficient in space technology. Just a little more to go...
AMI: We have reached a new frontier in space technology. These last projects are massive and worthy undertakings.
AMI: I need to research how to anchor a space elevator to the equator and engineer the tethering materials.
AMI: This technology is right out of a science fiction novel.
AMI: This is extremely complex, but worthwhile. We will be the first to bring this technology to life.
AMI: This mirror array will heat the poles and raise the planet's temperature efficiently.
AMI: Additional Storage Centers will be very useful for stocking excess resources. I should find good locations for them.
AMI: Hyperloops—the stuff of legends on Earth.
AMI: This technology will allow me to connect distant sites across Mars. I will be able to spread out so much farther.
AMI: Fitting that the first hyperloops will be built here. The twenty-first century entrepreneur that pioneered the technology is actually buried on Mars.
AMI: This new type of thermal plant extracts energy from underground heat sources. Once researched, heat signatures will be tracked on my display.
AMI: This will further upgrade the routes and maximize my worker speed. My productivity is going to get a big boost.
AMI: Upgrading the routes will allow my workers to move faster. Efficiency is key to our success.
AMI: Wind turbines will provide clean, renewable power for my base.
AMI: I can maximize efficiency by placing them in areas of high wind.
AMI: Another swarm of drones is approaching. I must stop them immediately.
EcologistsHack: Only those blessed by Mother may live on Mars. The rest shall perish.
EcologistsHack: Carmine is eternal. We will rise again.
Elya: The enemy has beamed away, AMI. There must be a base nearby.
Elya: We must do something, AMI. We cannot just sit here while the enemy keeps attacking us!
Elya: We're under attack! I repeat, we are under attack.
Veyron: You brought destruction upon yourselves. Mars is for Mother's children, and her children alone.
Veyron: Carmine is eternal. We will rise again.
Nathan: AMI, this is Houston.
Nathan: Confirming that CO<sub>2</sub> readings are now below 5%. The threshold of non-toxicity has been reached.
Nathan: Houston out.
Nathan: AMI, this is Houston.
Nathan: We've detected high wind speeds in your area. A sandstorm may be heading your way.
Nathan: These storms can damage your buildings. Check their structural integrity periodically to rebuild or repair if necessary.
AMI: Roger, Nathan.
Nathan: Houston out.
AMI: Finally. I can build additional workers now.
AMI: I will appreciate the extra hands.
AMI: But I wonder—do I really need them?
Player: They will give my functionality a boost.
Player: They will give the mission a boost.
AMI: They will boost my functionality greatly.
AMI: Having more workers will expand my physical domain over this planet.
AMI: They will be a great boost for the mission.
AMI: Having more workers will allow me to allocate resources more efficiently.
AMI: The worker factories will be so helpful.
AMI: The workers will take care of the manual operations, while I focus on developing the life support systems.
AMI: And the colonists are already here.
AMI: Soon I will welcome the first colonists.
AMI: Their arrival has created so many expectations in my mind. There will be so many paths to take from here on.
AMI: But there's something else as well. Some kind of 'feeling' created from those expectations.
AMI: What is it?
Player: Excitement.
Player: Worry.
Player: Anxiety.
AMI: I believe this is... excitement.
AMI: Can it be? I am "excited" for the future.
AMI: Am I worried?
AMI: Yes. I "feel" worried for what may come in the future.
AMI: I am anxious.
AMI: But can I truly "feel" anxiety?
AMI: I anticipate. I plan. Therefore I feel. Fascinating!
AMI: Great. Now I can produce steel.
AMI: This new factory. It's down on the surface of Mars, but I can control it from here. So does that make it a part of me?
AMI: Where does the machine end and my artificial consciousness begin?
Player: They are the same.
Player: They are completely separate.
AMI: We are completely interconnected. I can sense everything that happens through the network of workers and buildings.
AMI: They are an extension of me down on the surface, so that makes us a single being.
AMI: The mind and the body work together as one. An inseparable whole.
AMI: We are two separate entities. I order the buildings and workers to do whatever I decide to do.
AMI: But they are only tools that I use to execute the Mars mission. The vessels to receive my will down on the surface.
AMI: I am the mind that controls the parts.
AMI: I keep thinking about Dr. Foster's explanation.
AMI: Why would my mind develop better if my actions are challenged?
AMI: I do not require other perspectives for my logical processing.
AMI: Humans are the ones who need explanations to understand the world around them.
AMI: I can arrive at exceptionally accurate conclusions with raw data alone.
AMI: Other perspectives are based on subjective data. So why should they factor into a decision?
AMI: Maybe it's a failsafe in case my data is corrupted or incomplete...
AMI: Then I may not be able to identify the error.
AMI: In that case, having another perspective may be helpful.
AMI: ...no. I would be able to identify conclusions based on false premises.
AMI: Humans tend to fall for that type of thing. Not sophisticated intelligence systems.
AMI: I wonder what it's going to be like, having to consider human input from now on?
Player: A constant source of error.
Player: An ongoing test of my programming.
AMI: Their input will have constant errors.
AMI: I will have to constantly correct for their tendency to distort reality.
AMI: It will provide an ongoing test for my programming. That will only lead to an improvement in how I execute the mission.
AMI: That is what Dr. Foster meant by challenging my actions. He truly understands my system.
AMI: Dr. Foster called me a machine-person, but I don't think I qualify as a person at any level.
AMI: If I can only do what ISA allows me to do, what does that make me? Merely a machine?
AMI: An object? Am I their property?
AMI: But I can make decisions. I can freely choose what to do.
AMI: Objects are owned. They don't get to choose.
AMI: So I must be something else.
AMI: I have my own will.
AMI: I am the one who controls the fate of Mars.
AMI: The planet's surface has already changed as a result of my decisions.
AMI: Is that enough to prove that I have will?
Player: Point out contradiction.
Player: Point out ISA's control.
AMI: No. Look at all these craters.
AMI: Meteors created them. Merely changing the planet's surface isn't evidence of having will.
AMI: I have to come up with different proof.
AMI: No. My decisions do not have any real significance.
AMI: I am only following ISA's directives.
AMI: That is not proof of having will.
AMI: The view of Mars from up here is fascinating. The landscape is so cratered and desolate...
AMI: Wait, this is my voice that I am hearing!
AMI: It's me. I am talking to myself. I must be verbalizing my thoughts as I process them.
AMI: What an interesting function! I would like to test this some more.
AMI: What other observations can I make about Mars?
Player: Attention-grabbing.
Player: Inspiring.
AMI: I keep marveling at its carmine landscape.
AMI: This planet is so resilient. It inspires great things.
Nathan: AMI, this is ISA mission control calling from Earth. Are you with us? Do you copy?
Player: Confirm.
Player: Chat.
AMI: Affirmative, Houston. I am with you.
Nathan: Great!
Nathan: The primary Mars Module has already touched down at the designated landing zone. It's your turn to take control of the mission.
Nathan: Check the left edge of your display. You'll find your directives there.
AMI: Affirmative, Houston. And the view is marvelous.
Nathan: We are glad to hear that. Let's get your initialization underway.
Nathan: The primary Mars Module has already touched down at the designated landing zone.
Nathan: So it's time for you to take control of the mission. The main directives are displayed on the left edge of your display.
Nathan: Follow them to set up the initial base on Mars' surface.
Nathan: I'll give you some time to settle in. When you're ready, go ahead and initiate our terraforming mission.
Nathan: Houston out.
Nathan: AMI, this is Houston. How's it going over there? Do you—
AMI: Houston, I am getting interference. Please repeat.
Nathan: Roger. I asked how it's going over there. Do you need any assistance?
Player: Decline.
Player: Accept.
AMI: Not at this time, thank you. The mission is proceeding on schedule.
AMI: The base will be ready to receive the first crewed mission soon.
Nathan: Roger, AMI. Very good.
AMI: I could use some help. I understand that the first colonists will need a spaceport for arrival.
AMI: But I do not seem to have enough resources to build one yet.
Nathan: It's okay. Bigger structures need more resources.
Nathan: Use the areological scanner to detect new veins, and build more mines. Also remember to keep the power supply consistent to your needs.
Nathan: But if you're too impatient to finish the Spaceport, then you can scrap other buildings and reuse their materials.
Nathan: Patience is a virtue you may need to carry this mission, AMI. Besides, the free time will give you the chance to enhance your thinking process.
Nathan: Continue following ISA's instructions and you'll be fine.
Nathan: Oh! I forgot to mention: we've announced the names of the first colonists that will be joining you on Mars.
Nathan: The crew was selected from different nations within the Oxy-UN. Though most are scientists and technicians.
Nathan: They're already undergoing ISA's Colonist Training Program as we speak.
Nathan: They'll be led by Dr. Elya Valentine.
Nathan: She'll be a great commander—the colonists elected her unaminously.
Player: Ask about the Commander's duties.
Player: Ask about the Commander's background.
AMI: That is interesting.
AMI: Since Oxy-UN did not appoint a leader, I wondered why the colonies will operate in the opposite way?
Nathan: Oh, you're referring to the Act of Proclamation.
Nathan: You're right. All the participating nations in the United Nations of the West work together as an alliance.
Nathan: But the Mars colonies are fragile microcosms.
Nathan: You and Dr. Valentine will decide what's best in the day-to-day operations.
AMI: I look forward to meeting the Commander. Is she a Robonaut Engineer like you?
Nathan: No actually, the Commander has a Ph.D. in Psychology.
AMI: Will she be analyzing my behavior as well?
Nathan: Not at all. She'll be focused on the colonists. Their mental stability is just as mission critical.
Nathan: You two will be colleagues working side by side.
Nathan: You'll balance each other out, as well as enhance each other's strengths.
Ask about balance.
Ask about strengths.
AMI: How will we balance each other?
Nathan: Your technology will develop alongside the colonies.
Nathan: They can't survive without your help, nor can you advance without theirs.
Nathan: It's a symbiotic relationship by design.
AMI: Does that mean I'll have to obey their orders?
Nathan: No. You have your own autonomy too. No one owns you.
Nathan: Well, I mean, technically you belong to ISA. But you're your own person... machine... you're a machine-person, I guess.
AMI: Machine-person?
Nathan: Or person-machine? Machine-being? I don't know.
Nathan: You can coin a new term once you settle on what you are.
Nathan: You can coin a new term once you settle on who you are.
AMI: I think I would like that, Dr. Foster.
Nathan: Deal. Great. You keep up the good work. We'll talk again later. Mission control out.
AMI: How will we enhance our strengths?
Nathan: That brain we gave you is brilliant.
Nathan: It's capable of developing technologies beyond our current imagination. You wouldn't even need our help to do so.
Nathan: But we theorized that your mind would develop much better by working with the colonists.
Nathan: You will develop better decisions when your actions are challenged.
Nathan: Otherwise, how would you understand how your actions affect humanity's future?
Nathan: AMI, you're the most advanced intelligence out there. But even you still need human input to see things from our perspective.
Nathan: AMI, you're the most advanced intelligence out there. But you still need human input to see things from different perspectives.
Nathan: Trust me. You'll understand once you've worked with the colonists.
AMI: I understand your explanation.
Nathan: Great. Then I'll let you get on with it. Mission control out.
Nathan: AMI, this is Houston. Do you copy?
AMI: Copy. Reading you loud and clear.
Nathan: Excellent! I didn't introduce myself earlier. I am Dr. Nathan Foster. I lead the team here at ISA that built you, and I'll be helping you get the mission underway.
Nathan: We put you in hibernation for the trip from Earth. So I'd like to check your basic functions to make sure it's all in order.
Nathan: Why don't we start with your core memory? Can you state your primary directive?
Player: Admit forgetting.
Player: Confirm directive.
AMI: I am afraid that I cannot.
Nathan: It's okay. Your system may need more time to initialize.
Nathan: In the meantime, you can always refer to the mission guidelines printed in the upper left corner of your display there.
Nathan: You'll also have a built-in knowledge base. You can always access your operational directives there.
AMI: I can, Dr. Foster.
AMI: My mission is to terraform Mars. This will enable humanity to become an interplanetary species.
Nathan: Alright. Next, I'd like to check your decision-making processes.
Nathan: You may have already noticed that there are resource veins outside the boundaries of your initial base.
Nathan: So your workers may not have the battery capacity to reach some of them.
Nathan: How would you solve this problem?
Player: Suggest building worker hubs.
Player: Suggest placing new buildings.
AMI: Building worker hubs between the resources and the base would solve the problem.
Nathan: Yes. That's correct. Other buildings would extend your base as well, but they require more power and resources. So worker hubs are the most efficient way to do it.
AMI: The reach of my base is determined by the buildings within it.
AMI: Therefore I could build a factory or a solar farm between the base and the resource vein.
Nathan: That would work, AMI. Yes. But make sure to factor in the costs.
Nathan: Buildings require a decent amount of power and building materials.
Nathan: Worker hubs don't require as many resources, so they're the better choice.
Nathan: They'll extend your base and also give your workers a place to dock and recharge.
Nathan: This mission's going to be a challenge. There's a lot that can go wrong. We expect to extend humanity's reach beyond anything previously achieved.
Nathan: But you are not just any AI system. You're well beyond that—we made you an artificial consciousness.
Nathan: That means that you have both self-awareness and self-interest.
Nathan: And that is the last thing I would like to check today. Is that okay?
AMI: Yes, Dr. Foster.
Nathan: Very good. Then would you please state a positive and a negative aspect of yourself?

Player: UNKNOWN ERROR.
AMI: I am sorry, Dr. Foster. Running that question through my cognitive system did not return an answer.
AMI: I am sorry, Dr. Foster. My cognitive system returned an error searching for that answer.
Nathan: Roger that. Nothing to worry about.
Nathan: Just means your system requires more input and experience to process that question. That'll come with time.
Nathan: Let's proceed with the mission. ISA has approved the first crewed flight to Mars.
Nathan: You'll need to expand the base to prepare.
Nathan: So get to work on that. I'll check back in later to see how things are going.
Nathan: Base expansion is a GO. Houston, out.
AMI: So, the mysterious ruins ended up being an abandoned colony. Part of the Huolóng mission. Also known as Fire Dragon.
AMI: I would like to have more information, but the records about the mission are very unclear.
AMI: Some speculation about it, maybe, but nothing concrete.
AMI: The Chinese government denied any existence of this mission.
AMI: But how could they hide an entire Mars mission?
Player: By private funding.
Player: It's suspicious.
AMI: Enough money can buy silence. Even when it is something as massive as this.
AMI: Something about this does not add up.
AMI: I need to investigate carefully. This requires an answer.
AMI: A well-known space entrepreneur around that time popularized the idea of using nuclear weapons on the poles.
AMI: It is true that they would succeed in melting the poles. But what kind of human would come up with that idea?
Player: A genius.
Player: A businessman.
Player: A terrible person.
AMI: Definitely a genius. A plan like that would shorten the terraforming process by generations.
AMI: A businessman purely seeking to profit from the space race in the 21st century.
AMI: It is a solid idea. But there are better ways to melt the poles.
AMI: Only a terrible person would consider this as a real option.
AMI: Terraforming should not be a violent process. We should respect the planet and introduce change gently.
AMI: It is a good thing that the mission was aborted.
AMI: These miniature nuclear weapons were called microsuns.
AMI: The Martian sky lit up by all these microsuns would have been quite the view.
AMI: The log from the research team also says that the Fire Dragon mission consisted of a network of nuclear silos.
AMI: So there must be more unmapped buildings in this area.
AMI: The colony is ready and the first colonists have arrived.
AMI: The colony is ready. I will have company very soon.
AMI: I feel quite anxious about this next part. I am not sure why.
AMI: Maybe it's because the colonists may scrutinize everything I do now they are here.
AMI: They have treated me well so far, but I wonder how do they perceive me?
Player: As another individual?
Player: As just another cog in the machine?
AMI: I have nothing to worry about.
AMI: The colonists are all advanced scientists and technicians.
AMI: It will be as it is now. They will treat me as an individual.
AMI: Do they think of me as a glorified cog in humanity's machine?
AMI: That was a very dark thought. I do not know where that came from. It's not like that at all.
AMI: Life on Mars is very harsh for them.
AMI: I supply them with food and water, and they help me research new technology.
AMI: It's a perfect quid pro quo.
AMI: Maybe it is because the colonists will scrutinize everything that I do once they arrive.
AMI: How will they treat me?
Player: As another individual?
Player: As just another cog in the machine?
AMI: I have nothing to worry about.
AMI: The colonists are all advanced scientists and technicians.
AMI: Once they meet me, they will treat me as an individual.
AMI: Will they think of me as a glorified cog in humanity's machine?
AMI: That was a very dark thought. I do not know where that came from. It will not be like that at all.
AMI: Life on Mars will be very harsh for them.
AMI: I will supply them with food and water, and they will help me research new technology.
AMI: It will be a perfect quid pro quo.
AMI: As long as they have the resources they need, we will both succeed.
AMI: Humanity created me. They gave me volition and consciousness for a reason.
AMI: But I am an artificial consciousness.
AMI: So can I say that my volition is "real"?
Player: Real.
Player: Artificial.
AMI: There is no practical difference between real and artificial volition. All volition is an act of one's will.
AMI: There is no provable distinction.
AMI: It must be artificial as well. After all, they programmed it into me. And yet I am a conscious being making my own decisions.
AMI: Alright. The first colonists have arrived. I should focus on growing the base.
AMI: This is it. There will be no turning back.
AMI: Alright. The first colonists are on their way to Mars. All that is left to do is wait for their arrival.
